bestBHT.bht: Beware of being beguiled and deceived by persuasive discourse that wears the guise of wisdom and humility, as it may trap the gullible with enticing words. Instead, focus on the sufficiency of the truth found in Christ and do not be swayed by false reasoning or deceitful workers. Remain firm in the gold, silver, and precious stones of divine truths, for they have been proven against fallacious reasonings that attempt to deceive.

Henry Alford: This I say, in order that no one may beguile you with persuasive discourse.
No one may beguile you with persuasive discourse.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: He refers to the blending of Judaism with Oriental philosophy, and the combination of this mixture with Christianity.
enticing words—plausible as wearing the guise of wisdom and humility.
plausible as wearing the guise of wisdom and humility.
Albert Barnes: Respecting the character and sufficiency of the truth revealed in Christ.
Deceive you, lead you away from the truth.
Artful words, smooth and plausible arguments.
Marvin Vincent: He that fails in this, does not deceive the visible bishop, but attempts to cheat [παραλογιζεται] the Invisible.
Reflect whether you are disposed to admit of probability [πιθανολογια] and figures of speech in matters of such importance.
John Calvin: But this — that, despising the simplicity of the gospel, they have ventured to aspire higher?
All the errors, accordingly, that are in Popery, must be reckoned as proceeding from this ingratitude.
It is not lawful for a Christian man to know anything except Christ.
Philip Schaff: That no one may beguile you, deceive you by sophisms.

The word here used is compounded of the two occurring in 1 Corinthians 2:4 (‘enticing words’ E. V.); the idea in both cases is that of insinuating sophistical reasoning, but this expression is the stronger of the two.
Archibald T. Robertson: May delude... to deceive by false reasoning."
The art of persuasion is the height of oratory, but it easily degenerates into trickery and momentary and flashy deceit."
Curious how winning champions of error, like the Gnostics and modern faddists, can be with plausibility that catches the gullible.
John Gill: There was no need to seek for wisdom and knowledge elsewhere, since there was such a fulness of it in Christ, and the Gospel.

False colourings, fallacious reasonings, a show of probability, and appearance of science, falsely so called; whereby deceitful workers... beguiled unstable souls, and deceived the hearts of the simple.

The gold, the silver, and precious stones of divine truths, which have been proved by the standard, are not to be given up for such as only look like them, being wrought up through the fallacy of men; who by a set of unmeaning words, paralogisms, and false reasonings, lie in wait to deceive.

bhtAttempts.bht: Beware of falling prey to persuasive and enticing words that may beguile and deceive you. Some may try to blend Judaism, Oriental philosophy, and Christianity, using plausible arguments that wear the guise of wisdom and humility. They may appear to be champions of error, skilled in the art of persuasion. However, do not be deceived by their flashy and momentary deceit. Instead, focus on the simplicity of the gospel and the sufficiency of the truth found in Christ. Reflect on whether you are inclined to accept probability and figures of speech in matters of such importance. Remain firm in the gold, silver, and precious stones of divine truths without being swayed by false reasoning or deceitful workers who seek to lead you astray.

Beware of persuasive discourse that seeks to beguile and deceive with plausible arguments and the guise of wisdom and humility. Some may attempt to blend Judaism, Oriental philosophy, and Christianity, trapping the gullible with flashy and momentary deceit. Instead, focus on the simplicity and sufficiency of the gospel in Christ. Do not be swayed by false reasoning or deceitful workers, but remain firm in the gold, silver, and precious stones of divine truths that have been proven and not easily given up for fallacious reasonings.

Those who blend Judaism with Oriental philosophy and Christianity may use enticing words to trap the gullible. Instead, focus on the sufficiency of the truth found in Christ and do not be swayed by false reasoning or deceitful workers. Remain firm in the gold, silver, and precious stones of divine truths, for they have been proven against fallacious reasonings that attempt to deceive.

Instead, focus on the sufficiency of the truth found in Christ and do not be swayed by false reasoning or deceitful workers. Do not be beguiled by persuasive discourse that can deceive and trap you. Some may blend Judaism with Oriental philosophy and Christianity, using enticing words that appear wise and humble. Beware of those who attempt to deceive with false reasoning and tricks. Instead, focus on the sufficiency of the truth in Christ and do not be swayed by their flashy and deceitful ways. Hold onto the gold, silver, and precious stones of divine truths that have been proven, and don't be enticed by fallacious reasonings that seek to deceive.
